Award.AwardTitle: INFEWS N/P/H2O (SusChEM): Understanding structure and organization of receptors at water interfaces for discovery of phosphate recognition design principles
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Amar Flood of the Department of Chemistry at Indiana University and Professor Heather Allen at the Ohio State University are developing an understanding of how to bind phosphate selectively in water. Phosphorous is a non-renewable resource and a critical nutrient for enhancing crop yields to help feed the growing population of the planet. However, a significant amount of the phosphorous that is added as phosphate to agricultural fields is lost as run-off into streams and rivers. The resulting buildup of phosphate in natural waterways helps fuel algal blooms that kill off all other aquatic life, can lead to toxins in the municipal water supplies and, when in the oceans, leads to toxic seafood. For these reasons it is important to develop new chemistries for recovering phosphate dissolved in water. This project also involves the education of undergraduate and graduate students through interdisciplinary research training, the development of "Grand Challenge" lectures on closing the human phosphorous cycle, and the design of a new general chemistry course series.

Professors Flood and Allen aim to understand and discover the factors controlling the recognition of phosphate by making use of synthetic receptors organized in monolayers at water interfaces. These interfaces create potent environments with dielectric constants much below bulk water offering the potential to substantially enhance affinities, yet such interfaces are poorly understood. Such interfaces also serve as fundamental models for the sequestration materials needed to help close the human phosphorus cycle. This collaborative effort involves the synthesis of a series of receptors, the determination of the affinity and selectivity of phosphate binding to the receptors when they are organized at air-water interfaces, and spectroscopic studies to ascertain the geometries of the resulting phosphate-bound complexes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary and Highlights of the Intellectual Merits 

            In our project, entitled “Understanding Structure and Organization of Receptors at Water Interfaces for Discovery of Phosphate Recognition Design Principles,” we undertook some of the first studies looking at the different driving forces that govern receptor-mediated recognition of phosphate (H2PO4–) and other anions (chloride, bromide, iodide, nitrate, nitrite, sulfate) at aqueous interfaces relative to bulk solution. Higher affinities and novel anion selectivity profiles were observed that differ markedly from expectations based solely on the normally dominant role of the Hofmeister series and hydration energies in aqueous solutions. Using an integrated approach that unites synthesis and supramolecular chemistry with interfacial science and spectroscopy, we showed how the geometrical hydrogen-bond complementarity and surface ordering of charged receptors impacts phosphate-selective binding. We showed that hydration properties and electrical double layer at the interface are intricately involved in the binding and that they also provide a basis for reporting on the binding behaviors using surface-sensitive spectroscopies.

            Using a model recognition system based on arginine and surface-bound organophosphate, we showed that anchoring the receptor at the surface of water enhanced the binding energies by a factor of 10,000 relative to bulk. This factor was attributed to the unique microenvironment present at the interface. To understand how to design molecular receptors to harness this affinity, we studied a series of hydrogen-bonding receptors rendered amphiphilic to anchor them to the air-water interface. Variations in the receptor structures involved differences in charge (neutral/cationic), distribution of the charge, and number of surface-anchoring groups (one/two). By quantifying the phosphate affinity, we found that charge-charge attraction and hydrogen-bond complementarity, exemplified best by guanidinium-based receptors, conferred greatest phosphate recognition (affinity and selectivity). Anti-Hofmeister selectivity was seen in the preference for binding phosphate over chloride. At high ionic strengths, however, the phosphate binding was weakened attributed to screening of the electrical double layer produced at the interface. We found that surface-based spectroscopy based on infrared absorption was the most useful way to characterize binding affinities as opposed to Langmuir pressure-area compression isotherms.

Overall, interfacial anion recognition was influenced by binding site identity, a charged interface characterized by the electrical double layer, and receptor packing constituting the supramolecular superstructure inside the surface monolayer. To verify the role of hydrogen bonding as a chemical design element for achieving phosphate selectivity, use of a charged ammonium conferred only Hofmeister-type binding selectivity. The phosphate selectivity could only be competitively impacted using sulfate (SO42–), which shares the same geometrical complementarity as phosphate but enjoys greater charge-charge attraction. The preference for sulfate was remarkable given the substantially greater dehydration penalty needed to be overcome for interfacial binding. Thus, anion affinity benefits from the novel microenvironment of the ordered interface and from electrostatic attraction of anions, while selectivity remains under the control of the recognition partner’s complementarity to the specific anion of interest.

These studies of interfacial anion recognition helped advance knowledge and understanding within the fields of aqueous supramolecular chemistry and water-mediated interfacial chemistry. The work completed has helped to redefine the role of the interface in enhancing affinities over bulk, the seminal role of the receptor’s charge when engaging with anions, and the receptor’s structural complementarity to the targeted anions to confer selective binding over other anions. These findings provide a basis for designing the next generation of receptors for targeting the binding of specific anions at interfaces, and represent a potentially transformative and original concept in the design of recognition systems.

Summary of the Broader Impacts 

We have advanced discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. To this end, we trained a total of 6 undergrads, 2 grad students, and 3 postdocs. These coworkers have continued to play a role in STEM with undergraduates entering graduate school and one of the postdoctoral scholars starting their independent career as an Associate Professor. A total of 4 papers have been produced over the course of the project including the 2 more in preparation. Of note, these papers involved interdisciplinary activities and student cross-training between supramolecular chemistry and physical chemistry groups working together to address research goals. As a consequence of the interdisciplinary nature of the collaboration, the cross-fertilization of ideas has led to impacts in each other’s disciplinary areas. In addition, positive impacts are also expected in areas outside each of these disciplines, including biological phosphate hydration, materials design for phosphate sensing and sequestration, and an understanding of phosphate binding at interfaces within atmospheric aerosol systems. We have explored other benefits to society that include technology transfer by involvement with industry on interfacial anion recognition. The outcomes and findings of these activities have helped provide new design principles for phosphate capture with the possibility for having a long-term positive impact on closing the human phosphorus cycle.
